_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

The Vopak Industrial Infrastructure America (VIIA) St. Charles Terminal at St. Charles is committed to operating and maintaining our processes in a safe and responsible manner. We use a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs (ERPP) to help ensure the safety of the environment, the public and our workers. This document provides brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented and includes:

 - A description of our facility and the substances handled that are regulated by the EPA's RMP criteria;

 - An overview of our accidental release prevention programs;

 - The five-year history of accidental releases of chemicals that are regulated by EPA's RMP criteria and that meet EPA's criteria for reporting;

 - An overview of our emergency response program;

 - An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accident chemical releases from occurring and therefore adversely affecting the environment, public and ultimately our employees. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

VIIA St. Charles Terminal is a for-hire liquid storage terminal. Chemicals and refined petroleum products represent the majority of the bulk liquids stored, handled and transported in this facility. Products are received into and transported from the facility via ship, barge, pipeline, tank car and tank truck. 

At this time the facility is storing six RMP-regulated chemicals which are as follows:

    Ammonia (anhydrous)

    Ethylenediamine [1,2-Ethaneiamine]

    1-Pentene

    Propylene [1-Propene]

    1,3-Butadiene

    Propane



Pyrolysis Gasoline (PyGas) contains several of the chemicals listed above in regimented amounts (reference SDS for more information). Ammonia (anhydrous) and Ethylenediamine [1,2-Ethaneiamine] are not part of mixtures and are the only RMP-listed toxics found in the operation.  1-3 Butadiene is also ha

ndled at the facility and is listed for inclusion in the RMP Rule as a flammable. 



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to the prevention of accidental release of regulated hazardous chemicals. Our management system addresses each key feature of a successful prevention program including:

Process Safety Information

Process Hazard Analysis

Operating Procedures and Training

Maintenance and Mechanical Integrity Programs

Management of Change

Pre-startup Reviews

Compliance audits

Incident Investigations

Employee Participation plans

Safe Work Permits and other work derivative plans

Contractor Performance and Safety Plans



These individual elements of our prevention program are utilized to prevent accidental releases at the St. Charles location. VIIA and its workers are committed to the standard that these system management systems set for the way we conduct business. Our corporate annual sustainability goals act as a control to help ensure that we are meeting the highest standard for accident prevention. 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no releases of a regulated substance from a covered process in the past five years that resulted in onsite/offsite deaths, injuries, significant property and/or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

VIIA maintains various contingency plans which address federal and state regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. Each program provides essential planning and training for effectively protecting the environment and the public during emergency situations. Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan (Hahnville/St. Charles Parish). 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

These include routine work process management reviews/audits to aid in optimizing operational discipline and address process safety gaps. In addition, capital pr
oject reviews are slated to improve asset operation and performance and are ongoing for St. Charles.
